Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery closed vessel, amphora or oinochoe; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of lion (part of face, mane in added red, forelegs, and body remaining) to left; in field probably part of afilling ornament; below, two dilute bands, above one preserved ray.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
The sherd is also published in Beazley (1956) 'Attic black-figure vase-painters', p. 19, no. 9 and attributed to the Ceramicus Painter.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 452, no. B755)
CVA Cambridge II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain, Fascicule 11, Cambridge, Fascicule 2 (p. 39, pl. XX, no. 14)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0914)
